title: Does DMI dictates your monthly payment on chpt13 plan? - CA atty help!!
question: Just went to a bankruptcy attorney last Monday to review my chpt13 plan. I saw a lot of errors(i.e missing creditors/CA, etc.) but what surprise me is my DMI(disposable monthly income) on the paperworks showed roughly -$350(negative) but under the chpt13 plan, I was being recommended to pay to trustee $1300 per month!! Now this didn't make sense to me at all and I didn't sign it but I highly appreciate any thoughts or explanation from our expert attorneys here at avvo... pls help! Does it make sense to retain this attorney? I paid retainer of $1550 already and I'm frustated and worried I just got ripped off.. Do you guys think I can still get my moeny back...
question_tags: Child support,Alimony,Chapter 7 bankruptcy for businesses,Chapter 13 bankruptcy for businesses,Liquidating business assets,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Bankruptcy liquidation,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Foreclosure,Business
answers:
DMI is one of many factors. You payment is driven by DMI (which as others said is a legal fiction), actual disposable income (based on the schedules), the liquidation test (value of unprotected property), what the law requires you to pay (certain taxes, child support, spousal support) and what you have to pay based on what you want to accomplish (mortgage arrears, car payments).

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

As another contributor has said, DMI is a fiction resulting from the "means test'. This test basically compares your income and expenses to national standards and determines whether you are above or below the median income for your state. Above the median and you're expected to file a chapter 13 case; if below, you could possibly file a chapter 7 case. Sometimes under median debtors will still file a chapter 13 case if they are trying to avoid a mortgage foreclosure, for example. Since the "means test" looks BACKWARDS for six months from the filing date, it really is of no importance, in my opinion, in determining the amount of your payment to the trustee. That's what schedule I and schedule J are for. If you are not comfortable with your attorney, you can get another one any time you want. Go to nacba.org and use the "Attorney Finder" to find one near you.

You are experiencing the same frustrations that we bankruptcy attorneys experience. The DMI is a FICTION created by Congress in the Statutue, and quite candidly, it often makes no sense.

Depending upon what your agreement was with your attorney, you should be able to get at least a partial refund if you elect not to file.

Is it possible to downsize--maybe surrendering a vehicle to perhaps lower the payment? It most likely has taken you some time to get into this situation, and it may take some time to work your way out.

Good luck!! Carl Johnson

There are 3 variables that determine what your Chapter 13 payment must be...

What you want to pay, such as your mortgage arrearages.

What you need to pay, such as your priority taxes & child support.

What you are required to pay, which is how much you must pay on your unsecured (Sch F debts), determined by the results of the Means Test, or your DMI.

And finally, what you have available to pay, as shown on your budget (Your DMI)

You provided the numbers for the DMI, so if you don't like the results, find a way to change the numbers. Your attorney can't do it for you.

In a 1st draft of a Chapter 13, there are bound to be missing creditors & other minor mistakes for you to correct. Your attorney only has access to the information on your credit report & what you provide.

Look at your expenses & see if you can find something you didn't include. The Chapter 13 will require you to pay your entire DMI into the Plan. Sorry!
